document.docAuthor: Sandoval-Ruiz, César Antonio, Cervantesperedo, Luis, Mendoza-Palmero, Fredy Severo & Ibáñez-Bernal, Sergio
document.masterDocTitle: The Triatominae (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Reduviidae) of Veracruz, Mexico: geographic distribution, taxonomic redescriptions, and a key

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Triatominae (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Reduviidae) of Veracruz, Mexico: geographic distribution, taxonomic redescriptions, and a key

subSubSection.paragraph:
Reduvius dimidiatus Latreille
in Humboldt & Bonpland 1811 , p. 223 , pl. 15 , fig. 11 . Type locality: Peru , Tumbes.

Distribution. Belize , Colombia , Costa Rica , El Salvador , Ecuador , Guatemala , Honduras , Mexico (Campeche, Chiapas, Colima, Estado de México , Guanajuato, Guerrero, Hidalgo, Jalisco, Michoacán, Nayarit, Oaxaca, Puebla, Querétaro, Quintana Roo, San Luis Potosí, Tabasco, Veracruz, and Yucatán), Nicaragua , Panama , Peru , and Venezuela (
Lent & Wygodzinsky 1979
,
Zárate & Zárate 1985
, Vidal et al . 2000 ,
Galvão et al . 2003
).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 10–13.
Triatoma dimidiata
from Veracruz, Mexico: 10) Male from Municipality of Actopan, Rancho San José, IEXA; 11) Female from Municipality of Ixhuatlán de Madero, La Aguada, IEXA; 12) Female from Municipality of Tantoyuca, Palo de Rosa, IEXA; 13) Male from Municipality of Apazapan, Apazapan, IEXA. Photographs by C. A. Sandoval–Ruiz.

FIGURES 14–17. Triatomine species known to occur in Veracruz, Mexico: 14–15)
Triatoma dimidiata
; 14) Female from Municipality of Actopan, El Arbolito, IEXA; 15) Female from Municipality of Centla, El Refugio, IEXA; 16–17)
Triatoma gerstaeckeri
; 16) Female from Municipality of Chicontepec, Teponaxtla, IEXA; 17) Female from Municipality of Pánuco, La Angostura, IEXA. Photographs by C. A. Sandoval–Ruiz.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Comments.
T. dimidiata
is the most common and widely distributed species of Mexico , and probably the significant vector of Chagas disease to humans from the epidemiological point of view. It is distributed in all of southeastern Mexico and Central and northern South America (
Lent & Wygodzinsky 1979
). It is easily found in the wild, and in peri- and intradomestic environments. To date, it is considered a species complex with high morphologic, genetic, and ecologic differences, especially those populations from Yucatan peninsula and Central America (
Dorn et al. 2007
). In the state of Veracruz, it occurs in anthropogenic modified habitats as well as in dry and evergreen tropical forests.

During the revision of entomological material of
T. dimidiata
deposited at IEXA , we found specimens that show a wide variation of size, chromatic pattern, and morphological characters (see
Figs. 10–15
). Those differences make us suspect that in Veracruz there may be cryptic species and not just
T. dimidiata maculipennis ,
as was mentioned by
Usinger ( 1944 )
based on morphological features and
Bargues et al. ( 2008 )
with molecular markers. In addition, we have to highlight that all specimens revised were collected at peri- and domestic habitats. Nevertheless, the hypothesis about cryptic species in Veracruz and a possible differential epidemiological importance among these should be tested in the future.
